text:
310-312 (old Nos. 198-200) West 14th Street, south side, west of Eighth Avenue, the western two houses of a group of five, probably all alike, of the 1850 period. 14th Street has always been numbered east and west from Fifth Avenue, but it was not always the custom to start with a fresh hundred at every numbered avenue.
The older Dagget and Handdall Building (six stories), at 314 adjoining, replaced an old residence some time between 1902 and 1910. The occasion of making this photograph was probably the purchase of those two houses, with 306-308 adjoining, by the interests that demolished them and then erected a double six-story apartment house n the site
About 1912

14th Street, sourth side, from Eighth Avenue to Hudson Street and
Ninth Avenue, inclusive, showing the New York County National
Bank in its marble building, 77-9 Eighth Avenue on the S.W. corner
of 14th Street, erected around 1906 on the site of its older
location, 79 Eighth Avenue. By 1934 this building will be occupied
by a branch of the Manufacturers Trust Company.
Adjoining the bank is 306-12 West 14th Street, a double apartment
house built around 1913 or 1914 (see 310-12 West 14th Street, about 1912), and beyond it what used to be the Daggett & Ramsdell Building,
314 West 14th Street. In the middle of the block stands St.
Bernard's Roman Catholic Church (1873-5).
On the eastern side of Eighth Avenue, 14th Street is partially boarded
over, as work is in progress on the extension (opened 1932) of the
B. M. T. 14th Street subway.
May 31, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

Eighth Avenue, west side, north from W. 14th to 15th Streets. Shown at the N. W. corner of 14th Street is the New York Savings Bank. View 3 is limited to this structure. No. 2 is photographed from atop the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. It includes the New York Port Authority Building as a backdrop. On the right is the towering County Trust Building. This structure stands on the cleared site shown in the right foreground of View 1. Additional construction shown is for a new subway.

View 1: May 30, 1929
View 2: March 16, 1933
View 3: February 14, 1932

P. L. Sperr

This structure stands on the cleared site shown in the right foreground of View 1. Additional construction shown is for a new subway.

View 2: March 16, 1933

No. 2 is photographed from atop the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. It includes the New York Port Authority Building as a backdrop. On the right is the towering County Trust Building. This structure stands on the cleared site shown in the right foreground of View 1. Additional construction shown is for a new subway.

View 1: May 30, 1929
View 2: March 16, 1933
View 3: February 14, 1932

P. L. Sperr

14th Street, West from between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, showing south side, from the roof of the new County Trust Building at Eighth Ave and 14th street. St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church is in the left foreground.
May 31 1930

80 Eighth Avenue, at the N.E. corner of West 14th Street (County Trust Co. Building) general view northeastward.

A set of three views photographed in the direction of Madison Square and overlooking the zone between 14th and 23rd Streets. At that point appear the New York Life and the Metropolitan Buildings.

Thru the foreground runs Seventh Avenue, and the prominent New York Telephone Co. Building (No. 206 West 18th Street) is to the west of same. The side of this structure seen by the viewer is on West 17th Street.

To the right, and directly on Seventh Avenue are two tall structures. The first is a 12 story loft building, No. 106-110 Seventh Avenue (between 16th and 17th Streets), and the second, a new 18 story apartment house at the S.W. corner of West 18th Street. This latter structure is on the former site of the 3-story Arnold Constable and Co. stable (92-98 Seventh Avenue). In the near future another 18 story apartment will separate these buildings. This will be at the N.W. corner of 16th Street and abut the aforementioned loft.

In the distant background appears (view 3) the R. C. A., 10 East 40th Street, Lincoln, Chanin and Chrysler Buildings.

May 31, 1930
Views: 1, 2, 3

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - 8th Avenue - Northeast.

title: General view - 8th Avenue - Northeast.

text:
80 Eighth Avenue, at the N.E. corner of West 14th Street (County Trust Co. Building) general view westward).

Three views photographed from the above location towards the North (Hudson) River to show there various west side docks and ocean liners. These extend from Tenth and Eleventh Avenue's, and West Street.

Across the foreground runs the Ninth Avenue Elevated line crossing 14th and 15th Street's (in Views 1 and 2). View 3 is slightly to the south to show Gansevoort Street to the left. At the foot of same appears the group of buildings comprising West and Washington Market.

May 31, 1930
Views: 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - 8th Avenue - West.

text:
80 Eighth Avenue, at the N.E. corner of West 14th Street (County Trust Co. Building) general view south-westward.

Two views from atop the aforementioned structure towards the North (Hudson) River and overlooking the area to the west of Greenwich Village.

In the foreground is a small triangular block on the west side of Eighth Avenue (left corner) between West 13th and Horatio Streets. To the rear of same is West 4th Street and upon which stands the large 9 story Riker Hegeman Building.

May 31, 1930
Views: 1-2

P. L. Sperr
title: General view - 8th Avenue - Southwest.

title: General view - [Manhattan - 14th Street - 8th Avenue (South).]

text:
Eighth Avenue, at the S. W. corner of W. 14th Street (right) showing the former New York County National Bank building. This institution was absorbed by the Manufactures' Trust Company. Note in View 2 the changed title across the facade.

View 1: March 21, 1931
View 2: February 14, 1932

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, at the S. W. corner of W. 14th Street (right) showing the former New York County National Bank building. This institution was absorbed by the Manufactures' Trust Company. Note in View 2 the changed title across the facade.

View 1: March 21, 1931
View 2: February 14, 1932

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, east side, from 16th to 14th Streets, showing County Trust Company Building. Taken from S. W. corner of 16th Street, across excavation for Port Authority Building.
April 18, 1931.

P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1) 14th Street, east from Eighth Avenue, view from the twenty-two story Lawyer's Trust Company Building, favoring the south side.
On the south side, at 214-16 West 14th Street, west of Seventh Avenue, stands the newer Daggett & Randall Building, erected around 1918, eight stories tall. Then comes a rear view of the newly completed twenty-story apartment house on Seventh Avenue adjoining the S.W. corner of 14th Street, the twelve-story loft building on the S.E corner, erected a little prior to 1920, and the brand new Salvation Army Building aat 120 West 14th Street. On the S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue is Carson's 14th Street Store, built there after R. H. Macy & Company moved up to 34th Street.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

(2) A portion of the same and showing the back yards between West 14th abd 15th Streets as seen from the same point of view.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

(1) 14th Street, east from Eighth Avenue, view from the twenty-two story Lawyer's Trust Company Building, favoring the south side.
On the south side, at 214-16 West 14th Street, west of Seventh Avenue, stands the newer Daggett & Randall Building, erected around 1918, eight stories tall. Then comes a rear view of the newly completed twenty-story apartment house on Seventh Avenue adjoining the S.W. corner of 14th Street, the twelve-story loft building on the S.E corner, erected a little prior to 1920, and the brand new Salvation Army Building aat 120 West 14th Street. On the S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue is Carson's 14th Street Store, built there after R. H. Macy & Company moved up to 34th Street.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

(2) A portion of the same and showing the back yards between West 14th abd 15th Streets as seen from the same point of view.
June 16, 1931.
P. L. Sperr

80 Eighth Avenue, at the N.E. corner of West 14th Street (County Trust Co. Building) (general view westward).

Two views forming a panorama showing an inclusive view of the area between Gansevoort Street (left of No.1) and West 16th Street (right of No. 2). West 14th Street appears on the right of View 1 and shows at Ninth Avenue an "El" station of the line that derives its name from this thoroughfare.

In the background is the North (Hudson) River; various West Side piers and the Jersey shore-line.

In the foreground of No. 2 is the cleared site of the New York Port Authority Building (No. 11 Eighth Ave.). This structure will occupy the entire block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues and West 15th to 16th Streets.

June 18, 1931
Views: 1-2
title: General view - 8th Avenue - West.

text:
(1) A general view, northeast from the County Trust Company Building, at the N.E. corner of 14th Street, and Eighth Ave., showing in the background the Empire State (34th St and Fifth Ave) and the Chrysler (42nd St and Lexington Ave) buildings.

June 18, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, another view. June 18, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
Eighth Avenue, west side, north from 14th Street, showing construction work on Port Authority Building.
February 14, 1932.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

309-11 (Old No. 187-89 West 14th Street north side, west of Eighth Avenue, a double house probably built around 1850; it is on the maps as early as 1852. 14th Street has always been numbered east and west from Fifth Avenue, but originally it was not the custom to start with a fresh hundred at each numbered avenue.
July 16, 1932
P.L. Sperr

14th Street, north side, from Eighth to Ninth Avenues (northern end
of Hudson Street).
February 14, 1932.
P.L. Sperr

325-27 West 14th Street, north side, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, twin brownstones probably built not long after the Civil War.
July 16, 1932.
P.L. Sperr

A general view, southeast from 14th Street, at the northeast corner of Eighth Ave.
September 2, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
title: General view - [Manhattan - 14th Street - 8th Avenue (Southeast).]

text:
Eighth Avenue, south from W. 14th Street, as photographed from atop the Port Authority Building at No. 111 Eighth Avenue. The triangular park shown is Jackson Square. This is one block to the south of 14th Street and is bounded by 8th Avenue, Greenwich Avenue and Horatio Street. The tall apartment building there is at the S. W. corner of the last two thoroughfares and is identified as No. 2 Horatio Street.

April 26, 1933
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, south from W. 14th Street, as photographed from atop the Port Authority Building at No. 111 Eighth Avenue. The triangular park shown is Jackson Square. This is one block to the south of 14th Street and is bounded by 8th Avenue, Greenwich Avenue and Horatio Street. The tall apartment building there is at the S. W. corner of the last two thoroughfares and is identified as No. 2 Horatio Street.

April 26, 1933
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

County Trust Company Building, Eighth Avenue at N. E. corner of 14th Street, from 2 Horatio Street.
March 16, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Eighth Avenue, east side, from Greenwich Avenue, to W. 14th Street, as photographed from atop the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. Greenwich Avenue is the diagonal thoroughfare in the foreground and upon which is the white ventilator building (8th Avenue Subway) and the parking lot. 14th Street runs across the top, with its County Trust Company Building at the N. E. corner.

March 16, 1933
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, east side, from Greenwich Avenue, to W. 14th Street, as photographed from atop the apartment house, No. 2 Horatio Street. E. corner.

March 16, 1933
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr

(1)
Eighth Ave., south from West 14th to Hudson Streets and showing on the left, the western side of a small triangular park; Jackson Square. The buildings seen across same are Nos. 18 to 14 Horatio Street.

April 17, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A complete view of the block shown on the right of No. 1. These structures are Nos. 65 to 79; the latter being the New York County National Bank at the S.W. corner of West 14th Street. In the foreground of this photo appears the only entrance to the park which is on Greenwich Ave.

April 17, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A view slightly southward of No. 1; this being from West 13th Street (left). Photographers vantage point is on Eighth Ave. at Greenwich Ave.

April 17, 1937.
